awd_titl_txt: STEM Scholars Program:   Developing Tomorrow's Leaders in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at St. John's University in Queens, New York will support 70 academically talented, low-income students over a 5-year period to attain bachelor's degrees in biology, chemistry, mathematics and physics, to facilitate entry into the STEM workforce or advanced degree programs upon graduation. In addition to scholarships, students will receive support in the form of study skills workshops, tutoring, seminars, career-planning workshops, and peer mentoring by faculty. The project will also help to increase retention among all first-year science and mathematics students by establishing a group of faculty  who will introduce evidence-based high-impact education practices in introductory-level courses. Scholarships and support for low-income and academically talented students, who may not otherwise be able to obtain STEM degrees, will help to produce a well-trained workforce that will contribute to the economic well being of the nation.

The project combines a variety of approaches for improving STEM degree completion. A faculty working group called the Science Consortium will be created. These faculty expect to increase retention by improving introductory courses in degrees in biology, chemistry, mathematics and physics. Project faculty will be trained in evidence-based, effective instruction and high-impact education practices and will implement these in introductory-level courses. The core faculty team will serve as campus leaders training other members of the faculty and working together to fully transform the introductory-level science and mathematics curricula.  The project will utilize a sophomore seminar as a means to develop a scholarly community between commuter and resident student populations and to provide low-income academically talent commuting students access to high impact practices known to improve retention including collaborative assignments and projects, research with faculty, and service learning opportunities. In this sophomore seminar entitled "Solving the Big Problem," scholars will work in groups and choose their own problem to address under the guidance of faculty facilitators. Scholars will be encouraged to choose problems impacting the greater New York City area that can be analyzed using a multidisciplinary STEM approach. The seminar will form the basis around which a cohort of scholars will be established. The project will study how this seminar approach improves retention and helps low-income students, many of which are non-residential commuting, give these students a community build around curricular, and co-curricular activities. The study  will use a pre-post analysis of matched comparison groups to determine program effectiveness. The findings from the program will be disseminated widely to the STEM education community.

por.por_cntn:
The S-STEM program at St. John’s University, STEM Scholars Program (SSP), involved 63 students with 30 students receiving scholarship support for their last three years of their bachelor’s degrees. The overall goals of the program were: (1) to aid students in attaining bachelor's degrees in Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics, and Physics, and facilitate their entry into the STEM workforce or graduate programs upon graduation, and (2) to develop a consortium of faculty trained in evidence-based pedagogies and the implementation of high-impact teaching practices (HIPs) to renovate the introductory level science and math curricula. The SSP provided the three cohorts of science and math majors an opportunity to work together to create an interdisciplinary, scholarly, scientific culture on campus. Each SSP cohort consisted of 15 to 25 academically talented students who had access to curricular and co-curricular programs designed to provide academic rigor, support, and personal and career development.

To engage the students and form a strong cohort, the students enrolled in a two-semester CURE curriculum experienced the entire research process, from identifying a research topic, to carrying out the research, and presenting their results. In the first semester, the students were provided with an overall theme, and working in teams, they identified research topics, articulated research questions with specific aims, and developed research proposals. In the second semester, the teams operationalized their proposals, designed experiments and safety plans, carried out the research, and presented their results. The students chose their own research project based on a general theme; for the first year, the theme was water; the second year, a “big problem” of societal importance, and the third year, climate change.

In addition to the CURE offered in the student’s second year, we continued to engage the students by offering research opportunities in faculty member’s laboratories, hosting discussion sessions, regular meetings, and end of the year gatherings. Tthe first cohort of scholars hosted a discussion on Saving Jamaica Bay, a movie that depicted the changes in the Bay that borders southern Queens due to climate change and Hurricane Sandy. The second cohort watched Picture a Scientist in conjunction with the Clare Booth Luce and Women in Science programs. We also had scholars submit ideas to the NSF 2026 Idea Machine: one of which, Imagine a Life with Clean Oceans, advanced to the final round.

In terms of outcomes for the students, all our students, except one, graduated in six years. The one student took seven years to graduate. Our students enters graduate school, seven in the first cohort, six in the second, and six in the third.

The second major goal of the program was to develop a consortium of faculty trained in evidence-based pedagogies and the implementation of high-impact teaching practices (HIPs) to renovate the introductory level science and math curricula by using a four faculty-learning community (FLC) model. Four FLC were formed during the grant. The first FLC was composed of the PIs of the grant, and their focus was on the implementation of the STEM Scholars program and offering the “Solving the Big Problem” course-based undergraduate research program for the STEM scholars. The second FLC developed an academic-service learning program for their science and math courses, and the students in their classes built solar cell phone chargers for the students in a school in Puerto Rico that had been hit by Hurricane Maria. The third FLC investigated incorporating math skills into the chemistry recitations to help all students succeed in their introductory science courses, following the model that the School of Engineering at Wright State University developed. A fourth FLC was developed in conjunction with an NSF Research Coordination Network-Undergraduate Biology Education grant. The faculty in chemistry, biology and math from St. John’s University came together with faculty from surrounding two- and four-year institutions to focus on improving introductory biology, chemistry, and math courses, and improve the transfer pathways for the students at the community colleges. St. John's University has joined the HHMI Inclusive Excellence-3 Learning Community Cohort focused on achievement-oriented thinking and practices for first year science courses.

The SSP utilized some best practices in higher education (learning communities, cooperative learning, undergraduate research participation, a sophomore seminar course, and mentoring) along with financial assistance and support services to promote student success in STEM. The program focused on students who are financially disadvantaged and who are likely to be under-prepared, under-represented minorities, or women.

By providing an integrated network of financial, curricular, developmental, co-curricular, professional, and social support services, the SSP enhanced the quality of STEM education at St. John’s, increased the graduation rate for the students in the program, increased the number of students pursuing advanced degrees and entering the workforce in STEM, and contributed positively to the culture and diversity within the STEM departments and the broader University community.
